title: Kadayawan festival
paragraph1: The Kadayawan Festival is a thanksgiving to nature for the harvest and life in general, held in the city of Davao in the Philippines. Kadayawan is a native expression in the Dabawnon tongue. It’s derived from the word “madayaw” which means good, valuable, and superior. Back in the day, the ethnic tribes of Davao would come together to celebrate abundant crops, performing rituals that paid tribute to the nature gods. They used to display fruits, vegetables, flowers, rice, and corn grains on their mats and at the front of their houses as a sign of respect for the great year they’ve had. They used to sing and dance as well, much like what they do today. In the 1970s, then Mayor Elias B. Lopez, encouraged the different Davao tribes to showcase their thanksgiving rituals. In 1986, the Davao City government launched a project that aimed to unite the people during the turbulent times of the Martial Law. Back then, the name of the festival was called Apo Duwaling, after three natural wonders you can find the region: Mt. Apo, Durian, and Waling-waling. It was first officially renamed as the Kadayawan Festival in 1988 by then Mayor Rodrigo Duterte, and now, over 30 years later, it’s still being celebrated.
paragraph2: It is once a small gathering, that now is one of the highly-anticipated festivals in the Philippines. From the dynamic street dancing to the vibrant giant floral parade, Kadayawan has something for everyone. It is Held every third week of August that Dabaweños celebrates as a thanksgiving event and a tribute to the lumad, a collective group of indigenous people living in the city. This is what makes Kadayawan a unique festival.
paragraph3: The main highlight of the Kadayawan Festival is the parade with magnificent floral floats, street-dancing competitions and exhibits that showcase the island's original culture and history. If you visit Davao at this time, you will get a perfect chance to appreciate the wealth of Philippine culture, food, and traditions. Local people are open-hearted—they will be glad to share their joy with others.

title: Masskara Festival
paragraph1: The MassKara Festival of Bacolod City is one the biggest festivals in the Philippines that is celebrated every October. During this Bacolod Festival, many travelers flock to the city to witness the electrifying celebration. MassKara is derived from the words “mass” meaning “many” and “kara” meaning “faces,” thus calling it the Festival of Many Faces. Masskara Festival was created to lift the spirits of the locals and bring back the smiles on their faces. The smiling masks were a declaration of the people of Bacolod City that they will pull through and survive the challenges and tragedies that they are facing.  Because of the smiling faces of the mask, Bacolod City got the nickname of The City of Smiles. Believe it or not, the festival has been giving local and international visitors the chance to have fun, drink, and party on the streets of Bacolod for over 30 years now
paragraph2: Rodney Martinez, of the Arts Association of Bacolod-Negros, held workshops in Negros in 1979, teaching villagers how to build masks out of coconut husks and paper mâché. Originally, these masks were made solely for the purpose of selling them to tourists and earning money, rather than for a celebration that they had yet to imagine. Local people supposedly made colorful masks as a signature remembrance of the province and to attract foreign visitors' attention. Fortunately, the concept was a hit, and travelers began purchasing the masks because they were light and portable. They can also be worn while seeing the tourist attractions in Bacolod.
paragraph3: Expect a warm greeting from Bacolod residents, since the city is known as The City of Smiles. Festivals in the Philippines tend to bring out the friendliest side of everyone, so don't be afraid about making friends with the locals. They might even give you the best travel advice! The festival's music, like the festival itself, has had a colorful evolution. The festival has moved away from folk melodies and now uses a mix of Latin beat remixes and Philippine jazz to enliven the street dances.
paragraph4: The event continues to represent a time of year when people can 'throw away' their unhappiness or any pain they are facing, just as they did when it first began all those years ago. This is a new beginning or a new start for them. It is hailed as a breathtaking sight to witness and something that everyone should strive to witness at least once in their lives. It is also described as the world's longest festival, lasting a month and featuring many festivities, parties, and gatherings in commemoration of the topic.

title: Tuna Festival
paragraph1: General Santos City's Tuna Festival is a must-see attraction. Because of the quantity of tuna fish, the city is also known as the Philippines Tuna Capital. Yellowfin tuna fish abound in the waterways surrounding the city, making it one of the top tuna producers in the world. Furthermore, General Santos is regarded as a world-class tuna supply. It's no surprise that the residents painstakingly organized the Tuna Festival.  The General Santos City Tourism Association – a consortium of hotels, resorts, restaurants, travel agencies, and other tourism-related establishments, then chaired by Mrs. Liwanag Ferrer – staged an event at the Halieus Mall (now RD Plaza) in 1998 to celebrate the city's 30th city charter anniversary, which featured tuna cuisine through culinary competitions, exhibits, and other activities dubbed a Tuna Festival.
paragraph2: Since 1998, General Santos City has hosted an annual tuna festival. The vibrant event takes place in the first week of September every year, and it's when all things tuna is celebrated. For the country's largest producer of sashimi-grade tuna, this makes perfect sense. Unlike other fruit festivals like the Lanzones Festival and the Mango Festival, this is a celebration of all things tuna and the place to be if you want to eat tuna. The fact that this remembrance is a celebration of all things tuna sets it apart from all other celebrations in the country. It is certainly praiseworthy to visit during this event, with all of the lovely activities highlighting tuna as the key topic.
paragraph3: During the Tuna Festival, locals showcase the province’s bountiful catch with colorful, ocean-themed floats. Another activity that everyone’s looking forward to is the Sugbahan sa Dalan where a long line of grills is set up on the street and hundreds of kilos of tuna are grilled on the spot. And the best thing about this festival in the Philippines is, everything’s free. The scents of the fish can be a bit overwhelming, but the good news is that you’ll get used to them pretty fast. And if you actually like seafood and enjoy the scents, then there are no issues at all
paragraph4: Participating in the Tuna Festival would undoubtedly remind you of the Philippines' sea's abundant diversity and richness. It's also a great opportunity to mingle and learn more about the culture of the local fisherman as they go about their everyday lives along the coast. It is essential to enjoy and relax as this festivity will bring out the inner sea spirit of you.

title: Higantes Festival
paragraph1: Higantes Festival is one of the Philippines’ most awaited events because of how unique the locals of Angono celebrate this festival. During this time, higantes or giants made of papier-mâché parade the whole town. These giants vary in sizes and are dressed in colorful Higantes Festival costumes so beautifully that they always take the media and tourists’ attention. It is held every November 23 in the town of Angono in Rizal province known as the “Art Capital of the Philippines.” The Municipality of Angono likewise considers the ‘higante’ as the symbol of the people’s aspiration to be great in their respective field and contribute to the development and pride of this town which is home to two National Artists namely ‘Botong’ Francisco (Painting) and Maestro Lucio San Pedro (Music).
paragraph2: The Higantes, or papier-mâché giants, were created by locals as a sign of protest during Spanish colonization, as per Angono tradition. According to a study conducted by James Owen Saguinsin, a professor at Far Eastern University, the giants do not exist, and what the residents refer to as the higantes is a tall hacienda caretaker named Karias Tangkad, whom the inhabitants exacted vengeance on. Saguinsin also believes that the gigantic papier-mache first began after World War II, when National Artist Carlos 'Botong' Francisco commissioned Artemio Tajan, the first higante maker, to give a festive and joyful element to Angono's post-war fiesta celebration. The Higantes Festival Tagalog has evolved throughout the years with magnificent works of art, as evidenced by the stylish higantes sets each year, the colorful Higantes Festival costume, the activities, and more.
paragraph3: Higantes currently reflect the various barangays or smallest unit societies of Angono, such as the duck-shaped higante of a particular barangay, which is known for its one and only fried duck and 'balut.'  Mr. Perdigon Vocalan added to the excitement of the celebration by portraying the 13 barangays of Angono with two to four higantes that represented their personalities as well as the history of their barangay.
paragraph4: The primary procession of this celebration features Higantes and a musical ensemble. Parehadores are young girls dressed in brightly colored outfits. As a symbol of San Clemente, they are holding a sagwan, or wooden boat. Many people are also wearing and carrying fishing nets and other fishing-related items. Several parade teams compete against one another for the finest procession throughout the festival.

title: Mango Festival
paragraph1: Mango Festival is home to some of the sweetest, juiciest most succulent mangos you will ever see in the Philippines. The festival is held in Iba, Zambales. The event is a celebration of a bountiful harvest of mangoes and other agricultural products which the province is so known for. It is aimed to highlight the must-see attractions and places of interest in all its towns. Mangoes cultivated in Zambales particularly the Dinamulag variety of Carabao mangoes were cited as the world's sweetest mangoes by Guinness World Records in 1995 and the country's sweetest mangoes by the Department of Agriculture in 2013. In 2015, other events unrelated to the province's mangoes such as sports events were introduced while the province's fruit remain the centerpiece of the festival. The festival was first held in 1999.
paragraph2: This festival brings together locals and foreigners alike to savor and promote the island’s best mangoes. Since a large part of the city’s economy relies on the export of mangoes, it’s no surprise that there’s an entire festival dedicated to the fruit.
paragraph3: The mango eating challenge is one of the highlights of the Mango Festival, where contestants compete to see who can eat the most mangos in a set amount of time. And, of course, no Filipino celebration would be complete without a street parade featuring locals dressed in bright, mango-inspired costumes! Hundreds of them crowd the streets, swaying to the beat of the music in various costumes, exuding a genuine excitement. The Trade Fair, the Variety Show, and the mango-themed street parades are some of the other popular events to look forward to. There's also a street dancing competition, which is a must-see at almost any festival in the country. There's also a spectacular float procession, much like at all other Filipino festivities, with floats inspired by the luscious fruit.
paragraph4: The Mango Festival or also known as Dinamulag Festival lasts for at least 4-5 days, and there is a plethora of different events to enjoy. On its last day is marked by a coronation ceremony, where the winners of all the previous competitions in the mango festival are announced. After that, the festival is closed off with a spectacular fireworks display. The Mango Festival is a fantastic opportunity to experience some of the Philippines' tastiest mangoes. Simply make it a point to include the Mango Festival in your vacation itinerary if you happen to be in Zambales in April.

title: Bangus Festival
paragraph1: Bangus Festival is held in Dagupan City, Pangasinan, to appreciate the city's growing aquaculture, particularly the abundant bangus or milkfish harvests. The Dagupan Bangus festival is recognized as one of the three best festivals celebrated in the Philippines. The prestigious recognition is given by the Association of Tourism Officers of the Philippines and also by the Department of Tourism. Dagupan City in Pangasinan is also known as the Bangus Capital of the Philippines. There is no exact Bangus Festival date but it is a 10-day event held every April. Among the highlights of this non-religious festival are the bangus cook-off, street party, trade fairs and of course, the electrifying festival dance in the streets.
paragraph2: The Bangus Festival is the brainchild of former Dagupan mayor Benjamin Lim, seeking to promote the city as the Bangus (milkfish) Capital of the World. The festival made the Guinness Book of World Records in 2003 when it set the record for the World's Longest Barbeque which measured slightly over 1 kilometer and broke the long-standing world record by Peru in November of 1999 at 613 meters. A laser guided equipment was used to accurately measure the longest bangus barbecue. It was later taken by the town of Bayambang, Pangasinan in 2014.
paragraph3: Dagupan is a city located on the Lingayen gulf in the province of Pangasinan in Luzon and is one of the top producers of milkfish or bangus in the province. Bangus is considered the tastiest milkfish in the world. Because it is a big event, many media entities not just from the Philippines but across the world are covering this annual event in Dagupan.
paragraph4: The Bangus festival is merely a symbol of their culture. Furthermore, the festival features their indigenous goods, making it an ideal opportunity to experience Philippine culture firsthand. Furthermore, there are commercial and tourism fairs, which adds to the excitement. The culinary and garden fairs add to the overall appeal of the event. Trade and tourism expos have helped the Bangus festival garner followers from all over the world. People from across the globe have started appreciating the festival and anticipate the same each year.

title: Moriones Festival
paragraph1: It is one of the Philippines' oldest religious celebrations. The Moriones Festival honors Longinus, a half-blind Roman soldier who used a lance to puncture Jesus' side when he was on the cross. According to legend, when some of Jesus' blood went into his eyes, he regained his sight. Longinus became convinced that Jesus was indeed the son of God after witnessing this miracle and converted to Christianity. The event recreates the centurions' search for Longinus for this crime, with one member of the local community portraying Longinus, who is captured and recaptured multiple times throughout the festival in a lighthearted game of cat and mouse. This is a traditional activity held every Holy Week in the island province of Marinduque in the Philippines. But unlike other festivals in the Philippines, Moriones is, according to religious sectors, not a festive occasion.
paragraph2: The place of origin of Moriones Festival is in Mogpog. It first appeared in 1807 as initiated by the Parish Priest of the town. Moriones is derived from the word “Morion” which means mask or visor hence, the mask in the Moriones Festival costume. It is a part of the medieval Roman armor which covers the face. Moriones, on the other hand, refers to the masked and costumed men and women penitents who march around the town for seven days re-enacting the search for Longinus.
paragraph3: Every time this festival is held, Morions roam the streets in seven days, from Holy Monday to Easter Sunday. Not only this is held in the town of Mogpog but it is also done in the towns of Boac, Gasan, Santa Cruz, and Buenavista in Marinduque. Aside from the parade, there’s also a Moriones Festival dance and some short acts re-enacting what happened during the time of Longinus. Various towns also hold pabasa or the recitation of Christ’s passion in verse.
paragraph4: The highlight of this solemn tradition is the “pugutan,” a re-enactment of the beheading of Longinus on Easter Sunday. Over the years, Moriones Festival has gained attention from across the world, even international media are covering this. The festival draws about tens of thousands tourists to the island, according to Marinduque tourism officer Dindo Asuncion.

title: Sinulog Festival
paragraph1: Sinulog Festival or Santo Nino Festival is an annual religious and cultural festival in Cebu. The festival is thought to be the first of the most well-known festivals in the Philippines. People from all around the world came to see the events, not just Filipinos. The festival's beauty has earned it the name Mother of All Festivals among Filipinos and other Asians. The Sinulog Festival never ceases to impress its audience, from the dancers' colorful and well-made costumes to the stunning dances and music provided by the drums, trumpets, and native gongs. With the celebration’s evolution, the Sinulog Festival has become a month long tradition in Cebu. Sinulog comes from the Cebuano word “sulog” which means “like water current movement” which depicts the forward-backward step of Sinulog dance.
paragraph2: The Santo Niño de Cebú, one of the country's most notable historic treasures, is honored at Sinulog. The Portuguese navigator Ferdinand Magellan presented this statue of the baby Jesus to the Rajah Humabon of Cebu in 1521. This was one of the most significant events in Philippine religious history since it cleared the way for the country's conversion to Christianity. At the moment of receiving the holy image, it was said that Queen Juana, the main consort of Rajah Humabon, danced with joy holding this image of the child Jesus.The other natives followed her example, and this event was regarded as the first Sinulog dance. The same event was used as the basis for most Sinulog dances.
paragraph3: Tourists would never want to miss the opportunity to watch the festival as it grew in popularity year after year, and it became increasingly commercialized. The festival now includes events such as art exhibits, beauty pageants, picture contests, and singing and dancing contests, in addition to costumes and dances. Besides the religious part of the celebration, Sinulog is also well-known for its street parties before the day of celebration and during the day of the festival.
paragraph4: With the overwhelming amount of people who wish to witness the traditional celebration and the beauty of the culture it depicts, this grand festival remains as Cebu’s proudest attraction, along with the beautiful beaches and historical places. Aside from the Sinulog Festival, Cebu has a lot of tourist attractions and activities in store for you. Sinulog is one of the most-awaited events in the Philippines so expect to see a lot of people in the streets who will participate in the celebration.

title: Ati-Atihan Festival
paragraph1: The Ati-Atihan festival is a Philippine festival held annually in January in honor of the Santo Niño in several towns of the province of Aklan, Panay Island. The biggest celebration is held during the third Sunday of January in the town of Kalibo, the province’s capital. The name Ati-Atihan means to imitate Ati, the local name of the Aeta people, the first settlers of Panay Island and other parts of the archipelago. The festivity was originally a pagan celebration to commemorate the Barter of Panay, where the Aeta accepted gifts from Bornean chieftains called Datu, who fled with their families to escape a tyrannical ruler, in exchange for being allowed to dwell in the Aeta’s lands. They celebrated with dancing and music, with the Borneans having painted their bodies with soot to show their gratefulness and camaraderie with the Aeta who had dark skin. Later on, the festivity was given a different meaning by the church by celebrating the acceptance of Christianity, as symbolized by carrying an image of the Holy Child or Infant Jesus during the procession.
paragraph2: It is the ultimate jubilating, titillating, stimulating, riotous and frenetic aboriginal street dancing to the early primitive tempo and pulse of drums, participated in by different tribes in their full battle regalia as they crowd the principal streets of Kalibo rejoicing breathlessly to their religious vows.  The start of the procession is signaled by drums and whistles, and later punctuated by shouts of “Hala Bira!”
paragraph3: Dubbed as the Mother of All Philippine Festivals, the Ati-Atihan Festival is widely known not just in the Philippines but across the world. The Ati-Atihan Festival celebration consists of multiple events that happen in various parts of Kalibo town. You’ll never run out of things to do because Ati-Atihan has all kinds of events—from solemn masses, loud marching bands to partying on the streets.
paragraph4: The Ati-Atihan also bears a deep religious significance. The pahilot, a faith-healing tradition, is held during the festival where a Catholic priest rubs the devotee’s body with the image of the Santo Niño, with the belief that it heals both the body and soul. Many of the townsfolk believe in this ritual and there have been reports of barren women who have been able to conceive after the pahilot. Just like any other festival, Ati-Atihan will be so much fun and will help us interact with many people and learn different cultures in Kalibo, Aklan.

title: Dinagyang Festival
paragraph1: Dinagyang Festival is one of the Philippines' largest and most prestigious events. It explores the history of Filipino devotees' devotion to the Holy Child Jesus, also known as Sr. Sto. Nino. Dinagyang is a Hiligaynon word that means “merrymaking.” Just like the Sinulog and Ati-Atihan Festivals, Dinagyang Festival is one of the religious festivities in the Philippines that celebrates the feast of the Santo Niño and the pact between the Datus and locals. The celebration also recalls the advent of the Malay settlers and the history of Panay Island's fabled barter with the indigenous known as Ati. Dinagyang season in Iloilo City is on the first month of the year and highlighted with an Ati Tribe Competition every fourth Sunday of January. The players perform spectacular choreography in colorful tribal costumes and eye-catching decorations to portray socio-cultural and religious scenes from Panay prior to Spanish colonization and the introduction of Catholicism to the country.
paragraph2: The Dinagyang celebration began in 1967, when an Augustinian priest from Cebu gave a replica picture of the Santo Nino to a fellow Augustinian priest in Iloilo as a birthday present. Every Friday since then, a novena liturgy has been held at the San Jose Parish Church. In 1969, a tournament comparable to the popular Ati-Atihan Festival in Kalibo, Aklan province, was held. At the time, the Dinagyang was known as Iloilo Ati-Atihan, but when radio station Pacifico Sudario insisted on adopting a local word to separate the event from the well-known Ati-Atihan of Kalibo, Dinagyang became the official name almost a decade later.
paragraph3: The celebration of Santo Nino is marked with flamboyant costumes and traditional dances. The fun in this, especially for visitors, lies in getting acquainted with the local culture as well as getting a glimpse into the daily happenings in the country. Dinagyang is one of the most-awaited festivals in the Philippines because of its fun, lively, and colorful celebration. The festival’s major events include the fluvial procession, religious sadsad, and the Ati tribes’ dance competition. In addition, there are many exciting activities happening all throughout the month of January.
paragraph4: Vibrant colors and thundering drum rhythms are to be expected. Enjoy a spectacular performance mastered over months of preparation and physical exertion. Expect the crowd to yell hala bira, the dancers' battle cry to encourage them to keep dancing their best. If you don't mind standing, this incredible talent show is free. The parade path snakes through Iloilo City Proper, and you can see the performances from any place along it.

title: Pahiyas Festival
paragraph1: Every famous holiday in the Philippines is typically colorful, and the Pahiyas Festival is without a doubt one of the Philippines' brightest and brilliant festivals. Pahiyas, like most Philippine celebrations, is held to express gratitude for the abundant harvest. The town of Lucban, celebrates one of the country’s biggest, and most colorful harvest festivals every May 15, along with the towns of Tayabas, Sariaya, Gumaca, Tiaong, and Lucena City, the festivities are the Philippines best known harvest festivals to honor San Isidro Labrador, the patron of farmers. Residents of the town center adorn the facade of their homes with fresh harvest of fruits and vegetables such as squash, bittergourd, bananas and tomatoes. They also make pretty and colorful lanterns out of kiping, which is a leaf-shaped wafer laboriously made from rice dough.
paragraph2: The word pahiyas comes from “payas” which means to decorate or decorate. The Pahiyas Festival meaning can easily be noticed once you see the beautiful house decorations in Lucban, Quezon. The origins of the Pahiyas Festival can be traced all the way back to the 16th century. It wasn't like the festival we know now back then. Farmers would carry their harvests at the base of Mt. Banahaw and sell their wares. They gathered and celebrated humble feasts to thank the Anitos for their abundant harvests. Farmers, on the other hand, simply brought their produce to be blessed by the priest when the first church was completed. The following year, they had another rich crop as a result of their actions. As a result, they established a custom of bringing their harvests to the church for the Lord's blessings. However, the chapel eventually became too small to house the overflowing supplies.
paragraph3: The Lucban Festival evolved into the colorful harvest festival we know today, with people dressed in amazing Pahiyas Festival costumes marching through the streets and performing a Pahiyas Festival dance. Cultural shows, trade fairs, art exhibits, and numerous contests are all part of the Pahiyas Festival month celebration to help the tourism economy. That is exactly what happened. Locals from surrounding provinces, as well as visitors from other countries, are flocking to Lucban to see and photograph the Pahiyas Festival.
paragraph4: Locals believe that keeping the tradition alive was essential because it brought them away from deprivation and misfortune in their town. There are a handful of major town festival and bright festivals observed around the Philippines, thanks to the Filipinos' fun-loving enthusiasm and creativity. There are many activities that the residents and even visitors will both enjoy while also learning different cultures and interacting with different people.

title: Panagbenga Festival
paragraph1: The highlands of Baguio City in the Philippines has been known as the country’s Summer Capital. That’s why people make the long road trip to Baguio from Manila to escape the stifling heat of the lowlands and polluted cities in the metro. Another reason tourist travel to the City of Pines is the Baguio Flower Festival or Panagbenga Festival. Panagbenga is an annual flower festival in Baguio City, Philippines, that takes place every February. The word Panagbenga stems from a Kankanaey word that means blooming season. The history, customs, and ideals of Baguio and the Cordilleras are reflected in this celebration. It lasts for over a month and thrives thanks to the participation of the community. Since this is a month-long festival, there are a plethora of activities to enjoy and take part in, from the landscaping competition to the golf tournament. As is tradition with most Filipino festivals, a Grand Parade marks the beginning of Panagbenga Festival.
paragraph2: The Baguio Flower Festival began when lawyer Damaso E. Bangaoet, Jr., John Hay Poro Point Development Corporation (JPDC) Managing Director for Camp John Hay, offered the idea of organizing a flower festival in Baguio to the JPDC Board of Directors. The Board, chaired by Chairman Victor A. Lim of the Bases Conversion Development Authority (BCDA) and JPDC President Rogelio L. Singson of the JPDC, quickly approved the proposal. It was also determined that the Festival would take place in February each year. In October 1995, the Baguio Festival got its official logo from entries to the Annual Camp John Hay Art Contest. Professor Macario Fronda of Saint Louis University wrote a Festival Hymn after that. The rhythm and motions of the Bendian Dance, an Ibaloi celebratory dance, were also incorporated into the song. The circular movements of the Bendian dance represent the tribe's oneness and peace.
paragraph3: New activities and initiatives have been introduced as the Panagbenga Festival progresses. Tourists are enthralled by Baguio's offerings. The Cordillerans' inventiveness, togetherness, culture, and customs were praised. Cordillerans demonstrate their ingenuity by creating massive flower floats. During the Grand Float Parade, they will be paraded through the streets of Baguio. Along with this, the residents, primarily students, conduct a vibrant, colorful, and cultural street dance. The celebration arose from the desire of the people to create their own festival, one that was particularly Baguio.
paragraph4: Because this flower festival is one of the most anticipated festivals in the Philippines, expect the Panagbenga Festival to be crowded, and full of many fun and exciting events. Moreover, during the Baguio Flower Festival, the majority of the streets are lined with brilliant flowers, making every corner worth the time.

title: Lechon Festival
paragraph1: The Parada ng Lechon also known as roasted pig parade is a festival you must see in Balayan Batangas. The celebration is held annually on June 24, and the feast day of San Juan (Saint John the Baptist). During the Spanish and American administrations, families that had received substantial graces in the previous year would parade a lechon in the town plaza on June 24th, St. John the Baptist's Feast Day. The best demonstration of appreciation and reverence to their patron saint for the poor people of Balayan is the parade of lechon in the plaza, which is centered on the Roman Catholic Church. The sight of people parading lechons – combined with the centuries-old ritual of water dousing in regions where St Joho the Baptist is the patron saint – was certainly a sight to behold even back then.
paragraph2: A one-day celebration turned into a two-week affair, with a variety of activities (sports tournaments, singing and dancing competitions, magic and acrobatic shows, bicycle race, battle of the bands, ballroom dancing, beauty pageant, free concerts, fireworks show, and so on) held as a warm-up for the Parada ng Lechon. Aside from the extended celebration, the Hermandad and the hundreds of clubs in the Kanluran neighborhood brought beer drinking and live bands/combos to the streets, as well as enormous streamers/tarpaulins, joyful banners and buntings, colorful uniforms, and souvenir t-shirts. All of these elements combine to create a more profoundly joyous and energized environment throughout the fiesta.
paragraph3: Lechon is one of Batangas delicacy, and even in other provinces in the Philippines. It’s a main dish most batagueños have for celebrations or fiestas. According to the old villager, lechon was served before the Spanish arrived in the Philippines. The dish became a symbol of Batangas tradition to serve lechon during celebrations.
paragraph4: Every June 24, local and foreign tourists, small and large businesses, as well as national and international media, rush to Balayan, Batangas to watch and participate in the country's most welcoming, lavish, and distinctive fiesta celebration. Everyone is welcome and free to visit Balayan, Batangas to participate different events that they have.

title: Inug-og Festival
paragraph1: Layawan was the previous name for Oroquieta. From 1861 to 1879, the current city was a barrio in the Misamis province. Boholano peddlers were among the first settlers. Because there are so many stray animals along the river, the area was given the name Layawan, which means place of numerous stray animals.
paragraph2: Inug-og Fesitival, an ethnic celebration of the Suban-on culture, is held in conjunction with the city's weeklong festivities. During this time, there are street dancing parades, fairs, and other fiesta activities. It is held on every 14th of October in tribute to city\’s patron saint, Our Lady of the Holy Rosary.
paragraph3: “Inug-og” is derived from a Subanen word “Ug-og,” which means an intense shaking of a person\’s two (2) shoulders when he/she wants to balance a load placed between them. The Inug-og Festival also exhibits many Lumad customs and lifestyles. It also features the traditional courting of a Lumad Guy to a Lumad Lady involves placing a red cloth on the shoulder of the girl he is intended to court and waiting for her to accept it as a sign that she accepts the guy's offer.
paragraph4: The celebration pays tribute to the Subanen tribe, who live along the many rivers that run through the Mt. Malindang Ranges Natural Park (MMRNP), at the foot of which Oroquieta, Misamis Occidental's capital, is located.

title: Pintaflores
paragraph1: San Carlos City’s name during the 17th century was Nabingkalan, which is thought to have come from the name of the Chieftain’s daughter in the Negrito settlement that dominated the barrio at the time. This town was later bought by a Cebu resident, who converted it to a Christian village.
paragraph2: The city has its own celebration namely Pintaflores festival which held every 5th of November. The festival’s name is derived from the Spanish word pinta that loosely translates to tattoos and flores means flowers. It is celebrated in honor of its patron Saint San Carlos Borromeo.
paragraph3: There are also story behind the uniqueness of festival’s name is piqued by many traveler’s interest. It is said that the festival’s name is comes from the adversity and victory of Princess Nabingka that took the challenge to go to unexplored lands. The festival is based on the event happened with princess. After she settled on the island, she had an illness that required immediate attention. The residents began planting flower beds in the hopes of healing the princess, but the weather had other ideas, and the flowers failed to bloom. As a result, floral tattoos were used to treat the princess, thus the Pintaflores.
paragraph4: The festival is indeed a joyful event in the city as they celebrate in memory of the beginning of their city. The climax of the festival is a dance ritual performed by locals at the San Carlos City Auditorium. This comprises dancers with flowers painted on their faces, arms, bodies, and legs, as well as human flower formation incorporated into each performance.

title: Kalag-Kalag Festival
paragraph1: The Kalag-kalag Festival is held in Cebu City, Cebu, Philippines, and it revives the Filipino tradition of visiting relatives to fondly remember friends and family who have passed away. The thirteenth of November is recognized as All Holy People Day in most parts of the country. Mayor Renato Malabor, who also celebrates his birthday on November 2, created the Kalag-Kalag Festival. The normally gloomy images of coffins and skeletons were transformed into a cleverly staged introduction, transforming the rather upsetting night of All Souls Day into a fantastic night of celebration.
paragraph2: The festival is unique in that it showcases creatures that many people associate with Halloween. Creatures such as phantoms, aswang, and that’s just the beginning of neighborhood legends told by more experienced people to terrify the young ones. These creatures compete against one another in the Kalag-Kalag festival, where they are used to engage rather than frighten the crowd. Kalag-Kalag derives from the word kalag, which means ghost. It is well-known and often observed throughout the Central Visayas, particularly in Cebu.
paragraph3: Most people may expect a festival as a pageantry of bright clothes and a joyful atmosphere. The Kalag-Kalag festival, held every evening on November 2nd, All Souls Day, by the Municipality of Isabela, Negros Occidental, is a one-of-a-kind event.

title: Kamundagan Festival
paragraph1: The Kamundagan Festival, a month-long celebration marking Naga’s birth and rebirth, aims to preserve Naga’s history by “looking back” to the city’s old traditional values-laden culture and family life so that current and future generations do not forget their exceptional heritage.
paragraph2: For the past 25 years, Naga City has hosted the Kamundagan Festival. Following the Penafrancia festival in September, when the entire Kabikolan praised the Virgin Mary for her leadership and guidance in religious activities, Kamundagan (Birth of Baby Jesus or Nativity) is held throughout the month of December.
paragraph3: The nightly parade, which takes place just before the beginning of December and involves 27 barangays from the city, non-governmental organizations, and local business groups, is one of the highlights. The gorgeous and lit chariots portraying the Holy Nativity enliven the parade procession. The parade’s spectators also anticipate kirik-kiti or sparklers.
paragraph4: The Kamundagan Festival id being promoted by the local government for a combination of tourism and faith. Marian worshippers continue to visit Naga every December, in addition to the Penafrancia.

title: Sinadya sa Halaran Festival
paragraph1: The Sinadya sa Halaran Festival is a collaboration between Roxas City and Capiz Province. It’s a mash-up of a holiday in that it’s celebrated for both social and religious purposes. It is recommended during the first few days of December in honor of the Feast of the Virgin of the Immaculate Concepcion, who is also the patroness of Roxas.
paragraph2: The vast procession of festivities, the fluvial motorcade, and the lit waterway floaters are just a few of Sinadya sa Halaran’s colorful exercises. There’s also the traditional fish feast and a spectacular pyrotechnic show.
paragraph3: In the local tongue, Sinadya sa Halaran translates as “joy in sharing and appreciation.” The Sinadya and the Halaran, which were previously celebrated separately, now share the spotlight during the first weekend of December. The Roxas city group says there’s a lot to be thankful and share, and it’s all in this wonderful celebration, which includes “Diana” fireworks display, a gourmet festival, and a magnificent dance festival.
paragraph4: Sinadya sa Halaran is one Roxas City’s most important annual event, and it is a mash-up of two festivals – “Sinadya” City and “Halaran” Province – that fully encapsulates joy in sharing and thanksgiving. On December 4 – 8, it is recommended that you remember the religious rituals that characterize a true Capiceo soul. The dancing parade, “Higantes”, Fluvial Parade, Firework show, Mutya sa Halaran grandeur event, Coronation of the Fiesta Queen, and Agri-Aqua Trade Fair are among the festival’s highlights.

title: Giant Lantern Festival
paragraph1: The Giant Lantern Festival, also known as Ligligan Parul, is an annual event held in San Fernando during the month of December, which is the Philippine’s Christmas season. The festival’s primary attraction is the Giant Lantern Festival Competition, which takes place in mid-December. This is a competition amongst enormous lantern designers.
paragraph2: This is a century-old festival in the Philippines that began in 1904. However, the old locals believed that the event was inaugurated in 1904, but it was initialized or instantiated during the late years of 1908. The inaugural Giant Lantern Festival was held to commemorate Manuel L. Quezon, during his term. That’s because, at the time, President Quezon transformed and opened the famed Mount Arayat National Park, which paved the path for tourism in the city, allowing the residents to prosper.
paragraph3: Locals utilized lanterns that were only around 2 feet in diameter back in the day. However, as the annual celebration grows in size and scope, improvements were made, and it becomes increasingly larger and more illuminated. In fact, many lanterns now have rotors to enable for lantern movement while also optimizing lighting effects.The lanterns used today are no smaller than 15 feet in diameter. That’s five times the original size, and there are still those that want to perfect and build a much larger lantern to keep breaking the record.
paragraph4: The large crowd pour out into the town plaza and onto surrounding streets and alleys, virtually body to body. Children and adults alike climb trees or stand on outdoor tables, chairs, vehicle, and jeep roofs, and rooftops to obtain a better view of the Giant Lantern Festival’s dramatic competition and beautiful parade.

title: Shariff Kabunsuan Festival
paragraph1: The annual Shariff Kabunsuan Festival, a four-day long festival, which held on 15th of December, features parades, dancing, business forums, exhibits, and feasts in honor of Shariff Muhammad Kabunsuan, an Arab missionary from Malaysia who introduced Islam to Mindanao in the 13th century, long before Spaniards brought Christianity to the Visayas.
paragraph2: The Guinakit Fluvial Parade, which incorporates a reenactment of Shariff Kabunsuan’s arrival to Rio Grande de Mindanao, the island’s second-largest river, located in Cotabato City, kicks off the celebration.
paragraph3: The Arab missionary was supposed to traveled aboard a brightly colored boat known as guinakit. It has been the sailing vessel of Muslim ruler for many years. The guinakit is decorated for the parade which flaglets and brightly colored textiles.
paragraph4: This festival is significant in Cotabato City, and people are looking forward to the different activities planned for the week-long celebration. Cultural perfomances, Alimango Festival, Muslim Culinary Arts Competition, cultural musical showdown, Kulintang Ensemble Competition, Philippine Acrobatic Show, Inaul Fashion Show, and Photo Exhibit Contest are among the events.

title: Pasalamat Festival
paragraph1: The City of La Carlota, located in the province of Negros Occidental is also famous when it comes to their festival celebration. They have the “Pasalamat Festival” which primarily aims to feature the pride of talents, skills, and products of the La Carloteños, or the locals of La Carlota. Thus, embodying its title as the “Drumbeating City of Beauty, Music, and Dance.” It is also the place where the oldest and the most famous sugar mill in the province located and the birthplace of prominent boxing champions. The place is rich in agriculture, made use of rice for their consumption and of tobacco as a form of business in export.
paragraph2: Tracing the history of the place, the early settlement or civilization of La Carlota started in the Candaguit riverbank. Later, on the year 1856, that was the only time that the village called Mampunay was recorded by the historians followed by appointment given by the parish priest of a specific place to be a site of the settlement is called Simancas. During the Spanish occupation, the barrio of Simancas was merged with the municipality of Valladolid, and it was only removed from such merging in the year 1871 when the King of Spain declared a decree stating that Simanca will be a separate town. The followers of the King Carlos of Spain also called the “Carlistas” requested the creation of the place as a parish and it was granted in the year 1876. Moreover, the La Carlota was created as a chartered city in the year 1965.
paragraph3: The Pasalamat festival aims to look back to the past cultural and traditional heritage of the town as evident in the different prepared activities and competitions. This week-long celebration will surely be a hit for those who are looking for a different and higher level of vacation. So what are the activities and competitions at this festival? Some of which are the Dog Walk at the Festival Park, Muneco Vistuaro or the Doll Costume Design Competition, Rollo Y Pinta or the on the spot painting contest, Pyromusical competition, and the Football Invitation Cup.
paragraph4: They also have varied sports exhibition and tournament activities like Basketball, Shootfest, Tennis, Chess, Billiard, Palarong Panlahi, Pawasak, Marathon, Karatedo, Mountain Bike, and Boxing. Other exciting activities and competitions also include Battle of the Bands, SMB Night Street Party, Rhythm Competition, Awit-Sayaw Extreme Night, Party at the Park, Trisikad Race, Dog Show Competition, 1-Clock Timbangan, Festival Dance and Float Parade, Arena Dance Competition, and the Festival Queen. Of course, as a place rich in agriculture, there is also the “Agro-Trade Fair” whereas all the native products and delicacies of the locals will be presented and are both ready for exhibit and for sale. The rich cultural and historical heritage of the town gave a massive contribution to the way they celebrate their Pasalamat Festival. It is a reflection of how beautiful their town is despite all the circumstances that they have been through. Come, join, and enjoy the Pasalamat Festival.

title: Kuyamis Festival
paragraph1: Staged every second week of January, Kuyamis Festival is being celebrated annually as a Founding Anniversary of Misamis Oriental. Kuyamis Festival is derived from the coconut, locally called Kuyamis which is very abundant all throughout Misamis Oriental, from the Municipality of Lugait in the west to the Municipality of Magsaysay in the east, coconut trees are very visible when you travel around the Province.
paragraph2: History revealed that Kuyamis is the original name of Misamis, it is a variety of sweet coconut. Which was the staple food of the earliest known Negritos settlers of Misamis. The word Kuyamis was later corrupted to Misamis when Christianity was yet new in the Philippines. One of the main sources of livelihood in the province is coconut production. Based on the data released by the Philippine Coconut Authority, Misamis Oriental ranks number 5 among the top 10 major coconut producers of the country, with 102,622 hectares planted with coconut that makes one of the remarkable economic contributions to the province of Misamis Oriental.
paragraph3: In fact, one of the export-oriented manufacturers of premium coconut products with a thrust of maximizing the almost limitless potential of the coconut and of developing a full line of fine coconut-based food ingredients is situated in the Municipality of Medina, Misamis Oriental - the Axelum Resources Corp. that produces the Fiesta Brands.
paragraph4: That is why Misamis Oriental takes its pride to celebrate the full potential of coconut as their main focus of the festival and of course together with its indigenous people. The Father of Kuyamis Festival, Governor Bambi Emano is right of giving honor to Kuyamis or the Coconut through this festival because it is one of the main sources of income to the province as it generates the province's export earnings. The festival is also a way of thanksgiving for the bountiful blessings the coconut continues to give to the province, the celebration of the rich culture and of course the people of Misamis Oriental. So, right after our New Year celebrations, the fun doesn't end there because Misamis Oriental continues the fun and excitement with their series of activities for this year's Kuyamis Festival activities.

title: Lubid Festival
paragraph1: The streets of this city became a living display of the many forms that the town’s most famous product, abaca, can take a giant chair, a giant jar, a giant gown.Abaca was unmistakably the star of the show as the town celebrated its Lubid (Rope) Festival every year of July 8-16. Now in its fourth year, Lubid Festival (July 1-16) seeks to promote abaca and the town’s other products in the country and abroad.
paragraph2: Emma Bordeos, Malilipot tourism officer, said the town sent out street dancers in colorful costumes and paraded giant handicraft products to showcase the craft of artisans and the hard work of abaca farmers.She said 65 percent of the town’s population is directly involved in handicraft production, particularly the abaca twine.
paragraph3: This is our way of promoting other lubid products such as bags, which is already a known product in demand in the local and international market,” she said.Now in its fourth year, Lubid Festival (July 1-15) seeks to promote abaca and the town’s other products in the country and abroad
paragraph4: Emma Bordeos, Malilipot tourism officer, said the town sent out street dancers in colorful costumes and paraded giant handicraft products to showcase the craft of artisans and the hard work of abaca farmers.She said 65 percent of the town’s population is directly involved in handicraft production, particularly the abaca twine.“This is our way of promoting other ‘lubid’ products such as bags, which is already a known product in demand in the local and international market,” she said.

title: Pasungay Festival
paragraph1: San Joaquin had been holding the annual Pasungay during the third Saturday of January in time of the town’s fiesta, Iloilo 1st District Board Member Marcelo Valentin Serag said in a phone interview. The festival was called off this year due to the animal cruelty claims of some animal welfare groups. It is almost a year that Pasungay had been called off, and until now we still do not have a clear explanation if it is legal or not, he said. On Tuesday, Serag has brought up the matter during the SP's regular session. We want to open the issue again to seek help from the concerned agencies to help us bring back Pasungay, he said.
paragraph2: In his speech, Serag said then-Iloilo provincial veterinarian Silvino Teodosio commented that bullfighting in San Joaquin is not a blood sport but “is more of a wrestling match where each side comprises a bull and his human trainer.” Section 6 of the Animal Welfare Act states that: “Prohibition on animal fights -- it is prohibited to subject animals to fight such as, but not limited to dogfighting, horse fighting, and bullfighting. A person must not a) cause procure, permit, encourage, promote, organize or incite a fight in which an animal is pitted against another animal for whatever purpose or reason; b) advertise promote the intention to conduct such a fight...”.
paragraph3: “Despite the name, Pasungay in San Joaquin is anything but bloodless. It is not a blood sport. The animal involved do not attempt to head-butt nor attempt to use its horn to impale, puncture or piece any part of the body of its opponent,” he said, citing Teodosio. In line with this, Serag mulls to pass a resolution to the Department of Agriculture (DA) to revisit the Implementing Rules and Regulations of the Animal Welfare Act and to “reevaluate its conformity with the spirit of the Act, and if so warrants, to categorically state that Pasungay is not covered by the definition or contemplation of prohibited animal fights for is not bullfighting per se and that is part of culture that will be afforded due respect and allowed to flourish.”
paragraph4: The board member wants the National Commission for Culture and the Arts (NCCA) to declare the practice of Pasungay as “a long-time practice and part of the culture and tradition of San Joaquinhons. This for it to “be allowed to flourish in a climate of freedom and responsibility true to the ideals of culture as a human right, Serag said. The move to pass a resolution for the NCCA was also encouraged by the Department of Tourism in Western Visayas, as implored by the Sangguniang Bayan of San Joaquin in its resolution number 2019-13. “The festival should be founded upon a definite declaration of cultural significance for an argument favoring its continuity to succeed,” the DOT 6 said. Serag is hopeful that Pasungay will be staged again this year to showcase the culture, history, and legacy of San Joaquinhons to local and foreign tourists.

title: Caracol Festival
paragraph1: The financial center of the Philippines, the Makati City, celebrates its annual Caracol Festival during the last week of February every year. Unlike any other festivals in the country that has long been formulated, Caracol festival of Makati City has just recently declared as the City’s official festival. Makati is the house of the countries multinational and local corporations. There are a lot of the country’s major banks, department stores and foreign embassies lays at the streets of Makati. It is also the biggest Philippine Stock Exchange trading center. Makati is also known for its agricultural and entertainment industry.
paragraph2: According to history, Governor General of the Philippines Miguel Lopez de Legaspi during the Spanish colonial period had explored the swamps of the Pasig River once. He wanted to know the name of the place so he asked a native. But due to language barrier the native misunderstood his question to be in regards of the tide, so the native answered him “Makati, kumakati na” which means “Ebbing, the tide is ebbing.” From then on, Legaspi addresses the area as Makati. Distinct from other Philippine Festivals, the Caracol festival of Makati is in honor to Mother Nature’s preservation. It was only conceived in the year 1989 during the pursuit of the Department of Tourism of its Island Fiestas program. And on January 21, 1991, the local government of Makati declared Caracol Festival as the City’s official festival.
paragraph3: Caracol is a Spanish word that means snail. It becomes the symbolic representation of the festival as Makati people views the shell of the snail as a protection from the misfortunes that life brings. The idea that depicts the snails shell was adapted to the annual festival of the city. The Caracol festival is held through a tribal dance competition usually composed of students of different school divisions and levels in Makati. Each usually has over 30 to 50 number of participants. Having the theme in-lined with nature, the participants are dressed in colorful flowers, plants, exotic animals, aquatic creatures, forest animals and other ornaments and organisms connected to nature. They are judge in terms of their costumes, choreography, and their overall performance. The high light of the event is the street dance competition and the best in costume competition among the participants.
paragraph4: This festival shows that Filipinos aside from its religious inclination has a way to celebrate and be thankful of the abundance of nature. Beside from being a highly developed in terms of its infrastructural and modernized facilities of Makati they haven’t missed a chance to appreciate still the beauty of nature, thus they pursue and promotes its preservation through their yearly festival. Another colorful and extravagant festival we all have to be proud of. Let us continue to promote the preservation of Mother Nature, by supporting Caracol festival.

title: Kinabayo Festival
paragraph1: Kinabayo festival is an amazing event on Dapitan City’s social calendar. The event is held every year, with tourists thronging to this location. While Dapitan City is best known for its amazing history as home to the location where national hero and symbol of struggle, Dr. Jose Rizal was exiled, it is also home to amazing festivals such as Kinabayo. Dapitan is one of the few predominantly Catholic cities in the Mindanao region of the Philippines, and every year, almost 95% of the 75,000 residents of the city take part in a mix of traditional and exotic celebrations for the Kinabayo Festival.
paragraph2: While Dapitan City is best known for its amazing history as home to the location where national hero and symbol of struggle, Dr. Jose Rizal was exiled, it is also home to amazing festivals such as Kinabayo. Dapitan is one of the few predominantly Catholic cities in the Mindanao region of the Philippines, and every year, almost 95% of the 75,000 residents of the city take part in a mix of traditional and exotic celebrations for the Kinabayo Festival.
paragraph3: Kinabayo festival is held to celebrate the Patron Saint, St. James the Greater. At the core of the festival is the reenactment of the Spanish-Moorish wars, the Battle of Clavijo, previously known as the Battle of Covadonga in 722 AD.During this war, St. James the Great (also known as Senor Santiago in Dapitan) was said to show an apparition riding a horse and holding a sword. He was leading the Spanish to victory against the Moors. This story was adapted in Dapitan, which used to be overrun with Moorish pirates. When the Spanish Jesuit missionaries arrived, they sought the help of St. James the Greater to defeat the Moors. The Christian defenders were victorious against the Moorish pirates.
paragraph4: Since then, the Dapitanos have always re-enacted the Battle of Covadonga in honor of the intervention of St. James the Greater that also freed the city. The Kinabayo Festival is also considered a feast in honor of St. James the Greater, thus the local chant of “Viva Senor Santiago!” throughout the festival.

title: Mahaguyog Festival
paragraph1: Mahaguyog, the mixed word for “Mais, Halaman, Gulay, Niyog”, is a festival annually celebrated in the Municipality of Sto. Tomas to honor the bountiful blessing showered to the town. It’s usually celebrated at the last week of February to March 7. The origin of the festival dates back on early days where vast plantations of corn or Mais creates a golden shine on the fields of Sto. Tomas. It is told that the town is really known for being an exporter of good quality corns. As time goes by, more and more crops were being tilled one by one on the land of Sto. Tomas. The merriments praise the plenitude of the place that is settled at the slants of Mt. Makiling and the Mt. Malarayat mountain ranges. Santo Tomas in Batangas commenced its 12-day opening salvo Sunday for the Mahaguyog Festival with the novice singing qualifying rounds in recognition of the 347th town holiday festivity which falls on March 7. The novice singing rivalries supported the senior subjects and the elderly for the “Puwede Pa Kami” classification and the kids' Bulilit classification.
paragraph2: The two-week recognition will likewise highlight the road moving, mardi gras, serenata, band sticking or Rakrakan Blues, smaller than normal band and parade rivalry, scaled down games challenge, agroexchange reasonable and barangayan, excellence exhibition, theatrical presentation and the firecrackers display. The festivity began February 24 and will end up until March 7 for the devour day of Saint Thomas Aquinas, the town's supporter holy person. Coordinators for the Santo Tomas festivity have booked the day by day mass and the novena inferable from its prevalently Catholic populace. As brilliant and abundant as the vegetation that possess large amounts of the town, the Mahaguyog Festival is a word subsidiary of the compression of the town's fundamental items, for example, mais corn, halaman plant, gulay vegetables and niyog coconut.
paragraph3: The merriments praise the plenitude of the place that is settled at the slants of Mt. Makiling and the Mt. Malarayat mountain ranges. Santo Tomas in Batangas commenced its 12-day opening salvo Sunday for the Mahaguyog Festival with the novice singing qualifying rounds in recognition of the 347th town holiday festivity which falls on March 7. The novice singing rivalries supported the senior subjects and the elderly for the Puwede Pa Kami classification and the kids' Bulilit classification. The two-week recognition will likewise highlight the road moving, mardi gras, serenata, band sticking or Rakrakan Blues, smaller than normal band and parade rivalry, scaled down games challenge, agro-exchange reasonable and barangayan, excellence exhibition, theatrical presentation and the firecrackers display. The festivity began February 24 and will end up until March 7 for the devour day of Saint Thomas Aquinas, the town's supporter holy person. Coordinators for the Santo Tomas festivity have booked the day by day mass and the novena inferable from its prevalently Catholic populace. As brilliant and abundant as the vegetation that possess large amounts of the town, the Mahaguyog Festival is a word subsidiary of the compression of the town's fundamental items, for example, mais corn, halaman plant, gulay vegetables and niyog coconut.
paragraph4: Batangas is a province of hardworking people, and this is why it is also among the nation’s most progressive provinces. This is not to say that Batangueños do not have a celebratory nature. On the contrary, although the renowned provincial festival, the famous Ala Eh Festival, is known throughout the archipelago, most of Batangas’ cities and municipalities celebrate their own festivals. In this post, we list the festivals of Batangas for the benefit of those who may just be looking for a reason to pay this great province a visit. Please note that these festivals are predominantly planned by the tourism councils or offices of the different cities and towns of Batangas, and may change not only dates but also names over time.

title: Suman Festival
paragraph1: The “SUMAN FESTIVAL” is the biggest and grandest of all feasts in Baler, Aurora with a weeklong celebration from February 14 – 19. It features parade of floats uniquely designed, main streets and homes are decked with suman (a native delicacy), trade exhibits, fairs and competitions, and capped by the Search for Ms. Aurora.
paragraph2: Suman is the Filipino steamed rice cake. It comes in as many different forms as there are provinces, but the basic recipes is waxy (sweet) rice wrapped in leaves, then cooked. Suman is the ritual gift of HAGISAN. It is cooked with great enthusiasm by Tayabenses because Hagisan is an opportunity to share their prosperity. Bundles of suman are gaily tied in the pabitin, which is made out of a special kind of bamboo called bagakay.
paragraph3: Baler is one of the most beautiful and tranquil places to visit in Aurora. For people who visited here already, they knew exactly the different attractions offered for both local and foreign tourists. During the month of February, Baler celebrates an annual event to recognize the anniversary of the province and experience the HAGISAN activity, which feature their homemade Suman (a kind of steamed rice cake native delicacy) hanging on the main streets

title: Tinagba Festival
paragraph1: Tinagba Festival is an annual event. It is held in February, in Iriga City of Camarines Sur province. The main point of this festival is for locals to offer their first harvest of the year, as a celebration. This tradition has existed for many years – it is because of this pagan ritual that this amazing event still exists today. Tinagba Festival also coincides with Our Lady of Lourdes feast, so there is still some religious significance to it. But, the fact that this festival was a pagan ritual makes it clearly distinct from the array of religious festivals that the Philippines is best known for. The interesting thing is that. as much as the ritual is pagan in origin, it is celebrated by locals across the religious divide. The roots of the festival actually come from the earliest Bicolans, who would offer their harvest to the gods, as a way of thanking them and asking for the next harvest to be even more abundant.
paragraph2: But nowadays, that has drastically changed to include the activities we’re used to seeing in other Filipino festivals, like street dancing. beauty contests, parades, and sports competitions. It is actually impossible to talk about the Tinagba Festival without making mention of the elaborate parades that are characteristic of this festival. The locals bring out their best bull carts and motorized floats which are managed by men and women in traditional regalia that is just as colorful. And that’s just the tip of the iceberg. The Tinagba Festival includes many other side events, that you can participate in, or just observe. There’s the Extreme Bike Challenge, suitable only for the most avid mountain bikers. The 30-kilometer race is a thrilling event that anyone can participate in, as long as they register on time.
paragraph3: One thing that’s actually pretty great about this festival is that the activities change from year to year. Apart from the street dancing and the float parade, the only thing that’s become a staple in the last decade is the mountain biking race. All of the other events differ from year to year, so you really can’t be sure what to expect. Some of the events that were part of the festival in the last decade are beauty contests, film showings, photography contests, talent festivals, fireworks display, and many others. In fact, in 2019, the festival also included an invitational billiard tournament, where you got an opportunity to play with Iriga City’s mayor. The politicians and the government are heavily involved in the festival, and just with the funding. They organize some sort of conference for elementary and high school goers every year, which aims to engage the youngest festival attendees and educate them even more on current issues.
paragraph4: By bringing together locals from all walks of life, the festival lives up to its hype as a unifying factor for Filipinos in showing gratitude. The festive mood, the palpable joy as well as the warmth of the exuberant locals makes this a delightful festival to attend. Yes, it’s an incredibly fun festival, but there is so much more to it than just colors, music and games. The parade is a particularly memorable part of the festivals. The locals come out on their motorized floats, which are abundantly adorned with the best products the province has to offer. And with marching bands providing the music, it’s incredibly hard to just stand by and watch, and not join in the festivities. The wonderful thing about this festival is that it is not just about celebration and extreme sports. Raising awareness is also a very important part of festivals, be it about breast cancer or environmental changes. The 2019 edition of the festival also included a blood drive, which is without a doubt one of the best festival events to partake in. Attending the Tinagba Festival is sure to give you a glimpse into the life of the locals, as well as show you how the relation between traditional rituals has been interspersed with the religious practices of a modern Catholic community. It’s actually one of the greatest influences of Spanish Colonization. You would see different large and monumental churches and cathedrals such as Manila Cathedral, Paoay Church and so much more.

title: Bulawan Festival
paragraph1: The Bulawan Festival, an annual celebration of thanksgiving that also showcases ComVal’s culture and tradition and progress, took its name from gold mining. ComVal is located in Mindanao’s “Mineral Corridor” and its robust economy was partly propelled by mineral produce in barangay Mt. Diwata (Diwalwal) and other gold-rich barangays.
paragraph2: With its vast gold deposits, Davao Region’s Compostela Valley has gained the title “Golden Province.” But behind the minerals their mountains possess, the province is also home to different tribes practicing culture that share the same value as the bounty they hold.
paragraph3: To show gratitude to God who blessed them with such fortune, the province celebrates with its people through the Bulawan Festival. The festival, which is on its eighth year, is celebrated in the same week of its 20th Founding Anniversary on March 4-8.
paragraph4: Growing green for good governance is the theme for this year’s celebration, giving emphasis on initiating more programs for the environment despite the province’s continued development.

title: Abaca Festival
paragraph1: The Abaca Festival or formally known as Catanduanes Abaka Festival is a festival held each year in Virac, Catanduanes, Philippines. The celebration happens every 4th week of the month of May.
paragraph2: The festival is cognizance of the importance of abaca fiber or Manila hemp industry in the local economy and the need to showcase its versatility as a major source of livelihood and craft material which has brought Catanduanes fame and fortune. The festival will showcase the life and resilient spirit of the Catandunganon and its culture, as well as the uniqueness and exoticness of the island and its people.
paragraph3: Catanduanes Island is the native habitat of the endemic abaca plant (a banana relative) which is globally renowned for its strong fiber. In fact, the Philippines FIDA (Fiber Industry Development Authority) declared the island as the highest abaca producing province in 2010. In 2009-2013, The Philippine Rural Development Program (PRDP) and the Department of Agriculture, Bicol Region had 39% share of Philippine Abaca production, emerged as the biggest produce while overwhelming 92% comes from Catanduanes the biggest abaca producing province in the country. The island province is also home of the finest grade of abaca fiber.
paragraph4: Other key events in the five-day fest are competitions on Abaca Arch & Façade Entries, Festival Queen Competition, and Virtual Dance Showdown which will feature municipal contingents in abaca-inspired costumes interpreting local legends and folklore.

title: Carabao Festival
paragraph1: Carabao Festival is a unique festival held in the municipality of Pulilan, Bulacan every 14th of May. Even nearby provinces participate in this two-day celebration to join with the parade of beautifully decorated carts. According to Roman Catholic Church records, San Isidro was once hired as a labrador or laborer. On the farm where he worked, his landlord was astonished by his ability to finish his tasks despite coming late to work most of the time.
paragraph2: The townspeople celebrate the occasion in a hope for a year-long bountiful harvest. It is held with a two-day revelry where street dancing and a procession of decorated carabaos take place. A variety of multi-colored fruits, vegetables, flowers, candies, and other food crops are hung on bamboo poles and carts. These carts, pulled by the carabaos, serve as floats. The highlight of the fiesta is the genuflection or kneeling of the carabaos with its two front legs in front of the church as sign of reverence to Saint Isidore.
paragraph3: On the first day, farmers pay tribute to carabaos. Farmers brush their carabaos' skin until it is sleek and shiny, while the horns are rubbed with oil and given shine. Then, the carabaos are decorated with ribbons or sometimes painted and attached to carts. In the afternoon, farmers lead their carabaos to the church square to be part of the procession. At the church, the carabaos not only kneel for their blessings but also walk on their knees like penitents in front of the church.
paragraph4: Aside from the kneeling of the carabaos and the carabao race, equally entertaining activities are done such as exhibitions where marching bands’ majorettes dance and twirl their batons, and children’s drum and lyre bands perform as street dancers take center stage with various folk dances.

title: Saulog Festival
paragraph1: The Saulog Festival in Tagbilaran City, Bohol is an annual cultural affair honoring St. Joseph the Worker.  The City Government of Tagbilaran, at the helm of the preparations of the significant celebration slated April 22 to May 1.
paragraph2: This thanksgiving festival got its inspiration from the local word, “saulog“, which means to celebrate or to commemorate. Now on its seventh year, it was bigger and brighter than ever.
paragraph3: Saulog Festival is one festivity that Boholanos look forward to every year. It does not only aim to merit the city’s most beloved patron, but also to show to the world that Tagbilaran City is fast growing, developing and progressing deserving a place on the global tourism map.
paragraph4: Saulog Festival is a surefire way of keeping the locals, as well as tourists, excited for the month-long fiesta season in the province of Bohol. Yet amid all the preparations for the festival, it’s interesting to note how devout the Tagbilaranons are to their patron saint, doing everything and anything they can to offer their thanks and love for St. Joseph the Worker.

title: Sagayan Festival
paragraph1: The Sagayan Festival is held on Araw ng Lanao del Norte (Lanao del Norte Day). It was celebrated on June 28 - July 2.
paragraph2: A major event every July in the province of Lanao del Norte. A war dance of Maranao depicted in dramatic fashion steps of their hero, Prince Bantugan, took upon wearing his armaments, the war he fought in and his subsequent victory afterwards. Warriors would carry shield with shell noisemakers in one hand and double-bladed sword in the other attempting rolling movements to defend their master.
paragraph3: Datu Bantugan is the legendary hero of the Darangen, Maranao epic. His name connotes Brilliance, Fame, and Honor one who makes history, the pride of Bumbaran, Maramanay and Simban are among the several names attributed to Bantugan,which means Crown of the Ayonanâ.

title: Pagoda Festival
paragraph1: The Bocaue River Festival, also known as the Bocaue Pagoda Festival, is an annual religious celebration in Bocaue, Bulacan, Philippines. It is known for its river procession dedicated to the Roman Catholic relic, the Holy Cross of Wawa (Krus sa Wawa).
paragraph2: The Bocaue River Festival's devotion is connected to the Holy Cross of Wawa (Krus sa Wawa), a wooden item found flowing in the Wawa section of the Bocaue River during an onslaught of a typhoon in 1850. According to local legend, a drowning woman was saved after she clung to the cross – an event later characterized as a miracle. The cross later kept in a riverside church after its retrieval, is believed to have come from an old church which was razed in a fire. A fluvial parade has been held since then as a tribute to the relic.
paragraph3: The Bocaue Pagoda Festival has a cross which rides on top of a pagoda adorned with magnificent trimmings and guided by colorful bancas. Hundreds of people attend the procession for a nine-day novena, during which they feast and celebrate the legendary rescue of the Holy Cross from the Bocaue River. What is unique about the Bocaue Pagoda Festival festival however is the procession down the river with a huge ornately decorated pagoda float. The float is atop a barge and the river is the Pasig River. Thus is the Holy Cross of Bocaue brought down the river.
paragraph4: Today the Bocaue Pagoda Festival continues, part of it to remember the dead. This tradition will continue as usual with better order and safety. But for sure the Bocaue river festival will live on for a long long time.

title: Sandugo Festival
paragraph1: Annually, Bohol celebrates the “Sandugo Festival” in commemoration of the historical event which is the blood compact. The blood compact was done by Miguel Lopez de Legaspi (who was the leader of the Spain’s expedition) and Datu Sikatuna (a native Bohol leader). The blood compact they did signified the friendship they were to build among them.
paragraph2: Blood compact was a native ritual back then wherein each people participating will pour their blood in a cup, exchange cups with one another, and drink its contents. It was believed to happen on March 16, 1565 thus Boholanos celebrate the commemoration previously during the month of March but not as often as they are celebrating it nowadays. There were years as well that they completely forgot about it thus not celebrating it all together. Chatto Torralba (who was the provincial governor of Bohol from April 1975 to June 1992), saw the importance of the historical event therefore starting the “Sandugo Project” and anointing Mr. Loy M. Palapos as its chairman in order to give more attention to the annual celebration.
paragraph3: The initial celebration was successful even though there were just very limited time given to prepare for it and improvement could be seen in its subsequent celebrations. Government officials succeeded supported the project’s implementation and soon after, gained recognition not just provincial recognition or national but also international.
paragraph4: Initially, “Sandugo” was being celebrated on the month of March. Eventually, it was moved to July in accordance to the Tagbilaran Charter Day on the 1st and Bohol day on the 22nd of the month. Furthermore, it was said to be properly celebrated on that month as TBTK (Tigum Bol-anon Tibuok Kalibutan) is being celebrated during July as well wherein all Boholanos from all the parts of the world are gathered together in Tagbilaran City.

title: Coron Festival
paragraph1: “Coron” (also known as pottery) are products formed in a variety of shapes and sizes. This traditional industry is dated way back from the 17th century when the usefulness of the clay found in the hilly portions near the Bolo sea was discovered. This was figured out by the early settlers when they formed the clays into different shapes and sizes. They were able to use their product in cooking, drinking, and eating.
paragraph2: After some time, this product became the livelihood of the people transporting it to nearby towns and regions and taking advantage of the Coron products they are just using eventually giving birth to the Coron festival.
paragraph3: The festival’s highlight is the participation of both public and private schools and sectors from the town performing street presentations. All They prepare are sufficient for a week long celebration and entertainment for the locals and nonlocals alike.
paragraph4: The peek of the festival is the packaged devotion and prayer for Nuestra Señora de Salvacion (Our Lady of Salvation) which attracts many devotees and religious groups by a long procession participated by diverse local sea vessels heading to the home of the miraculous image being the Barangay Joroan.

title: Higalaay Festival
paragraph1: The name “Higalaay” came from the Visayan word “Higala” having the meaning of friendship thus translating the name of the festival to “Friendship Festival”. The name was related to the tagline of the city itself which is “the city of golden friendship”. The original title of the celebration was “Cagayan Festival” until the city government was changed on 2014.
paragraph2: August 28, 1728 was the date when the St. Augustine cathedral Church (being the first Christian church in the city) was finished. From that day on, the 28th of August was considered as the feast day of Cagayan De Oro.
paragraph3: The festival begins on the 1st week of August commemorating the feast day of the city patron St. Augustine lasting until the end of the month. The Kumbira Food Fair and Festival kicks off on August 17-19 at the Atrium of the Limketkai Mall. Since 1996 the Kumbira Festival, a brainchild of the city’s COHARA organization, has highlighted the city’s chefs, local culinary arts, competitions, and culinary schools on a global scale.
